title: 115_s1072
content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and establishes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to fund general legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness across various geographic regions in the United States. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with entities across the US, including rural communities, tribal lands, Native Americans, and tribal organizations. Legal services provided include housing-related assistance and family law support. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships for legal services in landlord-tenant cases, foreclosure proceedings, family law, income support, and criminal defense related to homelessness to reduce recidivism and facilitate reentry obstacles. Consultation is required in developing these partnerships. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships for legal services in various areas to assist homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary must consult with public and private entities to develop these partnerships and may require periodic reports on the services provided. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships for legal services to assist homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary may require periodic reports on the services provided. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. Expansion of VA's authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive assistance under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 or care in specific settings is outlined in an amendment to section 2062 of title 38, United States Code. The eligibility criteria for veterans to receive assistance or care in specific settings include therapeutic residence, community residential care, and settings funded by the Secretary. The Secretary may disregard breaks in assistance for determining 60 consecutive days of care. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code, is amended by striking subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d). SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. SEC. 6 extends financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing by amending section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code to allocate $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2017. Additionally, training entities for provision of supportive services are extended through 2017. The Comptroller General of the United States will study Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The study will assess program effectiveness and review efforts to improve privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Additionally, the requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans is repealed. SEC. 8. Repeal of requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans by repealing Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code. Amend the table of sections by striking the item relating to section 2065.
